pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:0.5: 41. The training rule on naked ascetics
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Vesālī in the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.1.2: At that time the Sangha was receiving an abundance of non-staple food.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.1.3: Venerable Ānanda told the Buddha, who said, “Well then, Ānanda, give the pastries to those who take leftovers.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.1.4: “Yes, Sir.” Ānanda had them to sit in a row and gave them one pastry each, until he accidentally gave two to a female wanderer.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.1.5: The female wanderers sitting next to her said to her, “This ascetic is your lover.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.1.6: “He’s not. He gave me two, thinking they were one.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.1.8: And a third time Ānanda gave them one pastry each, until he accidentally gave two to that same female wanderer.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.1.9: Once again the female wanderers sitting next to her said to her, “This ascetic is your lover.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.1.10: “He’s not. He gave me two, thinking they were one.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.1.11: And they started to argue about whether or not they were lovers.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.1: A certain Ājīvaka ascetic, too, went to that distribution of food.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.2: A monk mixed rice with a large amount of ghee and gave him a large lump.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.4: Another Ājīvaka asked him, “Where did you get that lump?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.5: “From the food distribution of the ascetic Gotama, that shaven-headed householder.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.6: Some lay followers overheard that conversation between those Ājīvaka ascetics.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.7: They then approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.8: “Venerable Sir, these ascetics of other religions want to disparage the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.9: It would be good if the monks didn’t give anything to the ascetics of other religions from their own hands.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.10: After the Buddha had instructed, inspired, and gladdened those lay followers with a teaching, they got up from their seats, bowed down, circumambulated him with their right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.11: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.12: “Well then, monks, I will lay down a training rule for the following ten reasons:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.13: for the well-being of the Sangha, for the comfort of the Sangha, for the restraint of bad people, for the ease of well-behaved monks, for the restraint of corruptions relating to the present life, for the restraint of corruptions relating to future lives, to give rise to confidence in those without it, to increase the confidence of those who have it, for the longevity of the true Teaching, and for supporting the training.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.14: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:1.2.15.1: ‘If a monk gives staple or non-staple food to a naked ascetic, to a male wanderer, or to a female wanderer with his own hands, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.1.8: any wanderer apart from Buddhist monks and novice monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.1.10: any female wanderer apart from Buddhist nuns, trainee nuns, and novice nuns.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.1.12: apart from the five staple foods, water, and tooth cleaners, the rest is called “non-staple food”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.1.14: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.1.16: if he gives by body or by what is connected to the body or by releasing, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.2.1: If it is an ascetic of another religion, and he perceives them as such, and he gives them staple or non-staple food with his own hands, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.2.2: If it is an ascetic of another religion, but he is unsure of it, and he gives them staple or non-staple food with his own hands, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.2.3: If it is an ascetic of another religion, but he does not perceive them as such, and he gives them staple or non-staple food with his own hands, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.2.4: If he gives water or tooth cleaners, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.2.5: If it is not an ascetic of another religion, but he perceives them as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.2.6: If it is not an ascetic of another religion, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.2.7: If it is not an ascetic of another religion, and he does not perceive them as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.3.2: if he does not give, but has it given;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.3.3: if he gives by placing it near the person;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.3.4: if he gives ointments for external use;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.3.6: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc41:2.3.7: The first rule, the training rule on naked ascetics, is finished.
